Simple and compact Nim fuzzing library based on the great fauxfactory. The primary purpose of the library is to generate random strings to test the security of common utilities to help defend your system.

Author: Jonathan Edwards
Version: 1.0.0
Copyright: 2015 Jonathan Edwards. Apache License 2.0

Imports

unicode, math, strutils, times

Lets

UnicodeLetters = ch
Unicode characters from 0 to high(int16)

Consts

Schemes = ["ftp", "sftp", "http", "https"]

Procs

proc genAlpha(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a length-long alphabetic string; All letters lowercase unless upper is true 
proc genAlphanumeric(length = 10; upper = true): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a length-long alphanumeric string; All letters lowercase unless upper is true 
proc genChoice[T](choices: openArray[T]): T
Generates a random item from choices 
proc genBool(): bool {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates either true or false 
proc genCjk(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns a random string made up of CJK characters
echo genCjk(8) # 鍖磎仓鰀襓被澙齪
proc genCyrillic(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns a random string made up of Cyrillic characters
echo genCyrillic(5) # "ЋӅДӈҧ"
proc genEmail(name, domain, tld: string = ""): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a random email address
echo genEmail() # lenPFfhV@example.gov
echo genEmail(domain = genAlpha(6)) # sRISqUvc@QazEsO.gov
proc genIpsum(words = 0; paragraphs: int): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generate a custom version of the classic nonsense Lorem Ipsum text 
proc genLatin1(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns a random string made up of UTF-8 characters
echo genLatin1(20) # ãÄñäÒ÷ûÿßôüàêÖÈéáòûÎ
proc genIpaddr(ip3 = false; ipv6 = false; prefix: seq[string] = nil): string {.
    raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Generates a random IP address
echo genIpaddr() # 65.62.237.168
echo genIpaddr(ipv6 = true) # 076d:5c0d:6ced:2649:b44b:af26:7b06:8db3
echo genIpaddr(prefix = ["this"]) # this.141.204.179
# Making sure it makes sense is up to you ;-)
proc genIpaddr(ip3 = false; ipv6 = false; prefix: openArray[int]): string {.
    raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Generates a random IP address with a given prefix
echo genIpaddr(prefix = [10]) # 10.163.127.20
echo genIpaddr(prefix = [10,3]) # 10.3.251.78
echo genIpaddr(prefix = [10,3], ipv6 = true) # 10:3:605d:b501:6cb5:4e1b:736c:f1c8
proc genMac(delimiter = ":"): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a random MAC address with either ':' (default) or '-' as the delimiter
echo genMac() # 34:ed:50:7b:11:d1
proc genNetmask(minCidr = 1; maxCidr = 31): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a random valid netmask 
proc genNumericString(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Returns a random string made up of numbers 
proc genTime(): TimeInfo {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a random time and returns a TimeInfo object
echo genTime() # Mon Sep 22 03:43:47 2701
proc genUrl(extended = false): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Generates a random URL. If extended is true, the URL scheme is generated from ExSchemes instead of Schemes 
proc genUtf8(length = 10): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}

Returns a random string made up of UTF-8 letters characters

CJK seems to dominate the ranges, which makes sense

proc genHtml(length = 10): string {.raises: [ValueError], tags: [].}
Returns a random string made up of html characters 
proc genUuid(valid = true): string {.raises: [], tags: [].}

Returns a random UUID

valid makes sure some of it makes sense. It doesn't actually make sure it lines up with valid UUID versions

proc asBytes(s: string): seq[byte] {.raises: [], tags: [].}
Output some string as a byte sequence This can be combined with most of the fuzzing functions
echo genUtf8(2).asBytes
# returns @[229, 137, 145, 229, 191, 131]
